Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Tailoring the Electronic Structure of Few-Layer Graphene for Electronic and Optoelectronic Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: This GOALI project aims to develop a systematic understanding of the key electronic and optical properties of few-layer graphene and to apply this knowledge to exploratory electronic and photonic devices. The project involves collaboration between academia (Columbia University and Case Western Reserve University) and industry (IBM T. J. Watson Research Center). Recent research has revealed the remarkable electronic and optical properties of single-layer graphene. Few-layer graphene retains many of the unique properties of single-layer graphene while also providing much more flexibility in electronic structure, including the availability of a tunable band gap. Through this research project, scientists investigate how doping, electric fields and crystallographic stacking alter the properties of few-layer graphene material. Measurement techniques supporting these investigations include electrical transport characterization, light absorption in the optical, infrared, and terahertz spectral ranges, and Raman spectroscopy of phonons. The studies examine both pristine few-layer graphene samples and films in electrostatically gated device structures, which allow tuning of carrier densities and applied electric fields. The knowledge gained from these investigations will inform research on distinctive electronic and optoelectronic device applications of few-layer graphene, such as field-effect transistors with high on-off ratios and tunable infrared detectors and emitters.
Non-technical: This project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science with potential technological relevance. The research investigates the electronic and optical properties of few-layer graphene, a material that consists of ordered carbon films of just a few atomic layers in thickness. The project uses this knowledge to examine model electronic and photonic devices based on this novel material system. Success of the research will expand our fundamental understanding of the properties of electrons in few-layer graphene and their interaction with electric fields and light. In addition, applications of few-layer graphene in electronics and photonics have the potential to impact fields ranging from information technology to environmental monitoring. Through integrated industry-academia collaboration, the program provides opportunities for the training of graduate and undergraduate students in materials and in device fabrication, characterization and modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The unique electronic and optical properties of single-layer graphene (SLG) have been the subject of much recent interest and have opened up many new directions for applications.  The distinctive linear dispersion relation found in SLG yields unique properties, but also limitations in terms of applications. The ability to control and modify the electronic structure in graphene is not only of obvious technological importance, but is also a fascinating scientific challenge, one that can teach us much about the behavior of electrons in nanoscale materials.

In this project, a team of university (Columbia University and Case Western Reserve University) and industrial (IBM Research Division at Yorktown Heights) researchers has investigated the potential of few-layer graphene (FLG) as an electronic and optoelectronic material. The research covers both the systematic studies of fundamental optical and transport properties of single and few-layer graphene and the development of novel graphene integrated devices for electronics and optoelectronics applications.

The team has investigated several key properties of graphene, including: (i) vibrational modes, and their dynamics and interaction with electronic transitions in FLG; (ii) AC transport properties of graphene with controlled doping, and the evolution of these properties following ultrafast photoexcitation; (iii) ultraviolet-visible optical conductivity of graphene with controlled doping and the role of saddle point excitons; (iv) light-matter interaction in coupled graphene-optical cavity systems.

The first study yields fundamental new insights into how the vibrational structure changes in FLG with layer thickness, crossing from the 2-dimensional (2D) limit towards the 3-dimensional (3D) bulk. The second and third studies shed new light on how the many-body interactions modify the transport properties and the optical properties of graphene. The last study shows that light-matter interactions can be significantly enhanced by coupling graphene to optical waveguides or cavities. This result has opened a route to a new generation of compact graphene photonic devices. The close industry-academia collaboration has provided exceptional opportunities for student training. The research supported by this project has resulted in 17 publications in peer-reviewed journals and 2 Ph.D. theses.
